dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, big news out of Tokyo, huh? The Olympics are happening, but with a pretty major caveat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, big news out of Tokyo, huh? The Olympics are happening, but with a pretty major caveat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, absolutely, Host_A. Uh, they finally made that call, didn't they? No overseas spectators at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, absolutely, Host A. Uh, they finally made that call, didn't they? No overseas spectators at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overseas spectators will be prohibited from attending the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, the games' organizing committee announced Saturday, a move they hope will mitigate the concerns of Japanese citizens over the risk that the games will seed Covid-19 outbreaks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's right. I mean, it's a huge bummer for a lot of people, but like, you kind of saw it coming, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's right. I mean, it's a huge bummer for a lot of people, but like, you kind of saw it coming, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. I think it's really to mitigate those concerns from Japanese citizens, you know, about, um, COVID-19 outbreaks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. I think it's really to mitigate those concerns from Japanese citizens, you know, about, um, C O V I D nineteen outbreaks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Overseas spectators will be prohibited from attending the Summer Olympics in Tokyo, the games' organizing committee announced Saturday, a move they hope will mitigate the concerns of Japanese citizens over the risk that the games will seed Covid-19 outbreaks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they really want to avoid any, uh, seeding of outbreaks there. I heard they sold like, between six hundred thousand and a million tickets overseas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they really want to avoid any, uh, seeding of outbreaks there. I heard they sold like, between six hundred thousand and a million tickets overseas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the organizers, approximately 600,000 tickets were sold overseas, although the Associated Press reported that number is closer to 1 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's a lot of tickets. I mean, they're getting refunds, which is good, but no travel cancellation fees covered, which, oof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's a lot of tickets. I mean, they're getting refunds, which is good, but no travel cancellation fees covered, which, oof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Tokyo Organizing Committee asserted that refunds for tickets would be issued, but Tokyo 2020 Chief Executive Officer Toshiro Muto said cancellation fees related to airline travel and accommodations previously booked would not be covered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? That's a tough pill to swallow for some folks. But, you know, what's really striking to me is, like, even though Japan has managed the pandemic pretty well...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? That's a tough pill to swallow for some folks. But, you know, what's really striking to me is, like, even though Japan has managed the pandemic pretty well...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although Japan has managed the pandemic better than most countries, with fewer than 460,000 confirmed cases and 9,000 deaths nationwide, Japanese are not in favor of proceeding with hosting the Olympics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, their numbers are actually quite low compared to other places.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, their numbers are actually quite low compared to other places.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although Japan has managed the pandemic better than most countries, with fewer than 460,000 confirmed cases and 9,000 deaths nationwide...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But still, eighty percent of Japanese citizens, um, want the games postponed or canceled. That's a huge number.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But still, eighty percent of Japanese citizens, um, want the games postponed or canceled. That's a huge number.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 80% of Japanese believe the games, which are scheduled to begin in July, should be postponed again or canceled altogether, according to a survey by national broadcaster NHK.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is! It really shows you the level of, like, concern. And you think about, what, fifteen thousand athletes alone, plus all the support staff, media...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is! It really shows you the level of, like, concern. And you think about, what, fifteen thousand athletes alone, plus all the support staff, media...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 15,400 athletes will enter Japan to compete, in addition to coaches, officials, sponsors and members of the media.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a massive undertaking. So, uh, no easy decisions there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a massive undertaking. So, uh, no easy decisions there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, definitely not. What happens next, then? I heard something about the torch relay kicking off soon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, definitely not. What happens next, then? I heard something about the torch relay kicking off soon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, the torch relay actually starts this Thursday in Fukushima. It's gonna be four months long, ten thousand runners.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, the torch relay actually starts this Thursday in Fukushima. It's gonna be four months long, ten thousand runners.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The torch relay for the games will begin Thursday in Fukushima Prefecture and will last four months, with roughly 10,000 runners traversing the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's a big, um, tour. And I actually just saw that Prime Minister Suga announced they're lifting the state of emergency in Tokyo.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's a big, um, tour. And I actually just saw that Prime Minister Suga announced they're lifting the state of emergency in Tokyo.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this week, Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga announced the government planned to lift the state of emergency in Tokyo on Sunday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a positive sign, isn't it? Shows the hospital bed utilization has improved, so that's good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a positive sign, isn't it? Shows the hospital bed utilization has improved, so that's good.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The utilization rate of hospital beds has improved to the point that the state of emergency can be lifted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, a lot of moving parts, but, uh, at least they've made a decision on the spectators.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, a lot of moving parts, but, uh, at least they've made a decision on the spectators.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. It's gonna be a unique Olympics, that's for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. It's gonna be a unique Olympics, that's for sure.
